title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો

gujarati.couplet:

સંબંધી શ્રીમહારાજનાં, સતસંગનો શણગાર<RHYME_212922>.
gujarati.context: The couplet describes the residents of Ayodhya as being blessed with Hari's (God's) family and adorned with good company and noble character.

પછી સંગે તેડી તેને શ્યામ<RHYME_212923>, આવ્યા પ્રભુજી ગઢડે ગામ<RHYME_212923>.
gujarati.context: The couplet describes the peaceful life of a person in Ayodhya, who has found happiness and contentment with Lord Shyam. After this, they join Lord Shyam's procession and come to their village as a devotee.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

તેને આપ્યાં ઊતરવા ઘર<RHYME_212924>, ઘણું ઘટિત સારાં સુંદર<RHYME_212924>; 
પછી કરી છે રૂડી રસોઈ<RHYME_212925>, જમ્યા માવ ભાવ તેનો જોઈ<RHYME_212925>.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.context: After leaving Ayodhya, the traveler has shared their story; questioned about country, city, and village, everything has been revealed to its depth.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

પૂછ્યાં શહેર બજારો ને ઘર<RHYME_212924>, પૂછ્યાં ત્યાગી ગૃહી નારી નર<RHYME_212924>.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:

gujarati.context:
Here is a 1-2 line summarization of the Gujarati couplet:

The devotees have asked for and received from Hirimandir-Dharmashala, and traversed all paths; they have been blessed by God at every place.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:
પછી કહ્યું વાસી અયોધ્યાને, કાંઈક દીઠાં સાંભળ્યાં છે કાને; 
સર્વે યથારથ નવ્ય જાણું, એમ કહીને જોડી છે પાણું.
gujarati.context: After visiting Ayodhya, I've heard something extraordinary is happening in my ears; it's as if everything I know is being transformed, just like the river water mingles with the sea.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:
પછી બોલ્યા આપે અવિનાશી, તમે સાંભળો અયોધ્યાવાસી; 
જે જે સ્થળનાં લીધાં છે નામ<RHYME_212932>, તેમાં ફરતા અમે આઠું જામ<RHYME_212932>.
gujarati.context:
Here is a summary of the Gujarati couplet in English:

When someone speaks truthfully, listen as if you are from Ayodhya; whatever place's name has been given, we will roam around that only once.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો
gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:

gujarati.context: Life's fleeting moments are enjoyed and memorized, while small friends bring joy; one wanders far, crossing great rivers in their lifetime.

gujarati.context: We reside in our home for a little while, and today's joy is fleeting elsewhere; I am bound to my Lord's story, and nothing else concerns me.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:
ગમતા ભક્તિવાન ત્યાગી જ્ઞાની, ભૂંડા લાગતા દેહાભિમાની; 
હતો સ્વભાવ ચટકીદાર<RHYME_212937>, કઠણ વચન ન સહેતા લગાર<RHYME_212937>.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.context: As the conversation flows smoothly, the night passes in joy; then comes the morning light, and I reveal what was asked with mercy.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

The elder asks the wise Sundarshyam about our family name, seeking to know more about their heritage.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:
બાલપણામાં અમે નીસર્યા, કુળ કુટુંબનાં નામ વિસર્યા;

gujarati.context: In our childhood, we were carefree and forgot our family name; therefore, follow the tradition of your family with your loved ones.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:

gujarati.context: The people of Ayodhya spoke the truth, listen to their joy; I will tell you what they know, my name is Shyam.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

પુણ્યવાન પાંડે કન્હિરામ<RHYME_212923>, રહે સર્વારે ઈટાર ગામ<RHYME_212923>;

gujarati.context: Pandavas, the virtuous ones, lived in Ithaka village with Lord Sri Krishna; their names were Balakrishna, Subhadra, and Bhima.

gujarati.title_trans: Prakaran 91: Ayodhyāprasādjī ne Raghuvīrjīne Āchārya Karyā ne Vasant Panchamīno Utsav Karyo

gujarati.couplet:
તેના સુત એક સુભમતિ, દોષે રહિત દયાળુ અતિ;

gujarati.context: The couplet describes someone who is pure in heart and free from faults, with a merciful nature that forgives others; it also likens them to the avatar of God, Hari Prasad, which is a manifestation of divine love and compassion.
gujarati.title_gu: પ્રકરણ ૯૧: અયોધ્યાપ્રસાદજી ને રઘુવીરજીને આચાર્ય કર્યા ને વસંત પંચમીનો ઉત્સવ કર્યો

A virtuous person like Kanhiram resides in a village called Ittar; Their offspring will be blessed with good fortune and prosperity.

transliteration.couplet:
Tenā sut ek Subhmati, doṣhe rahit dayāḷu ati; <RHYME_19>
Nām Hariprasād te kahīe, te to Dharmano avatār lahīe.  <RHYME_19>
transliteration.context: One who has mercy and compassion without flaws is considered very good; he is known as Hariprasad, the incarnation of righteousness.

transliteration.couplet:
Moṭā yashvāḷā sahu jāṇe, sārā swabhāv sahu vakhāṇe; <RHYME_20>
Evā Hariprasādno kahu, jenā puṇyano pār na lahu.  <RHYME_20>
transliteration.context:
A great soul knows its own nature and describes it accurately.
Hariprasad is said to have no wealth except the good deeds he has done.

transliteration.couplet:
Luṇāpāranā Travāḍī kahīe, Bāḷkṛuṣhṇanā Kālu te lahīe; <RHYME_21>
Tene gher chhe Bhavānī nārya, te to ati pavitra udār.  <RHYME_21>
transliteration.context: The summary is: The Ganges River says something, and Lord Krishna's name is said; In Bhavaniji's home, there are many women who are very pure and noble.

transliteration.couplet:
Tene traṇ sut sutā traṇ, teh kahu suṇo asharaṇ sharaṇ; <RHYME_22>
Visharām Subuddha Ghelahi, Kālu sut kahyā traṇ tehi.  <RHYME_22>
transliteration.context: A parent's guidance and advice are like a shield that protects their child from harm, providing solace and shelter. A wise parent is one who imparts wisdom to their child, leading them away from danger.

transliteration.couplet:
Chandan Vasantā ne Bāḷābāī, Kālu sutā e traṇ kahevāī; <RHYME_23>
Chandanpati Pānḍe Saradhār, Vasantāpati Baldhidhār.  <RHYME_23>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes the contrast between Chandan's calm and gentle nature (like spring) versus Bālābāī's turbulent and chaotic personality (like a storm).

transliteration.couplet:
Bālābāī je nishche Bhagati, tenā Hariprasādjī pati; <RHYME_24>
Kahu teno have parivār, tame sāmbhaḷo prāṇ-ādhār.  <RHYME_24>
transliteration.context: One who has devotion to God is blessed with a loving husband like Hariprasad; their family is prosperous and their lives are stable.

transliteration.couplet:
Tenā sut sukhrūp traṇ, tame sahit bhav-dukh-haraṇ; <RHYME_25>
Moṭerā te Shrī Rāmpratāp, bījā tame Shrī Harijī āp.  <RHYME_25>
transliteration.context:
With good deeds, one can overcome sorrow; with devotion to Lord Krishna, all sorrows will fade away.

Lord Sri Ram and Sri Hari are the same, both bring joy and happiness.

transliteration.couplet:
Trījā Ichchhārāmjī kahevāy, jenī moṭyap kahī na jāy; <RHYME_26>
Beu bhāī atishe udār, jeno yash uttam apār.  <RHYME_26>
transliteration.context: Three desires are hard to obtain, even a small one is difficult to reach elsewhere. A brother with excessive generosity is extremely praiseworthy and unmatched in his glory.

transliteration.couplet:
Sarve rītye sukhiyā chhe eh, ek tam vinā dukhī teh; <RHYME_27>
Nīlkanṭh āvyā tame āī, bījā keḍye rahyā je be bhāī.  <RHYME_27>
transliteration.context: All pleasures are fleeting without the Lord's guidance, and one is miserable without a guru; just as seeds remain in the soil until they sprout with the right climate.

transliteration.couplet:
Kahu teno have parivār, tamane maḷavā ichchhatā apār; <RHYME_28>
Rāmpratāp ghere Suvāsī, te to tam vinā hatā udāsī.  <RHYME_28>
transliteration.context: One's own family is dearer than anything else; even if one gets everything in the world, it can't compare to the joy of being with them.

transliteration.couplet:
Tenā traṇ sut ek sutā, tenā nām param punitā; <RHYME_29>
Nandarām ne Ṭhākorrām, trījā Ayodhyāprasād nām.  <RHYME_29>
transliteration.context: The couplet praises the names of Lord Krishna and his consort Rukmini as most sacred, with the latter being the epitome of purity. The second line refers to the holy city of Ayodhya, blessed by the three worlds.

transliteration.couplet:
Sutā Shrīdhanubā niradhār, Pānḍe Jokhanno parivār; <RHYME_30>
Nandagher chhe Lakṣhmī nārya, Rāmsharaṇ sut niradhār.  <RHYME_30>
transliteration.context: A child is not tied to a specific family or social standing, just like a lotus flower remains untouched by the mud surrounding it. Similarly, Lakshmi's daughter Nandagher is free from worldly attachments.

transliteration.couplet:

Ṭhākorrām gher Shivkuvarī, Rāmsukh sut do dīkarī.  <RHYME_31>
transliteration.context:
Here is a summary of the Gujarati couplet:

Nārāyaṇprasād Harichandra's children are lovely and beautiful; similarly, the sons of Shivkuvarī are also very good.

transliteration.couplet:
Ayodhyā gher sunandā nārya, kahyo Jokhanno parivār; <RHYME_32>
Ichchhārām gher Vasumatī, jene Prabhu māhi prītya ati.  <RHYME_32>
transliteration.context: The city of Ayodhya is filled with beautiful women, and the Jokhano family's household is renowned; The Vamsamati family's home is filled with ardent devotees who love God intensely.

transliteration.couplet:
Tenā putra pancha puṇyavān, sutā beu te kahu nidān; <RHYME_33>
Gopāḷajī Raghuvīr nām, Vṛundāvan vaḷī Sītārām.  <RHYME_33>
transliteration.context: A virtuous son is born with good deeds, and his mother's words are the cause of his downfall.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context:
Here is a 1-2 line summarization of the Gujarati couplet:

The five brothers, Nath and Fuli from Badari, have a sister-in-law named Fulzari. They are a family bound by relationships and living in Gopali's house with Menā's ladies.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: The couplet describes two places where goddesses reside: Raghuvireni's house has Viraaja, and Vrundavana has Indira; similarly, Sitaram's house has Indira.

transliteration.couplet:

Kahetā suṇatā tehanā nām, thāy pavitra pāmiye dhām.  <RHYME_36>
transliteration.context: The Hariprasad family is extremely kind and generous. They are so pure that even the name of their home is considered sacred.

transliteration.couplet:
Vaḷī e deshnā je rahevāsī, te paṇ tam vinā chhe udāsī; <RHYME_37>

transliteration.context:
The couplet suggests that a person who has settled in their own country feels incomplete without others; even when they have many comforts, they still feel a sense of longing.

In the absence of others, even if one has many material possessions, they will still experience sorrow.

transliteration.couplet:
Em kahyu chhe Manchhārāme, suṇī līdhu chhe sundar Shyāme; <RHYME_38>
Pachhī pūchhī bījī bahu vāt, suṇī sahu thayā raḷiyāt.  <RHYME_38>
transliteration.context:
In the shade of a lovely tree, Manchara and Shyama are sweetly entwined; their love is as fragrant as the breeze that rustles the leaves.

The couple's love is like a seed sown in fertile soil, nurturing and growing with each passing day.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: The days of spring had gone by, and then the summer season arrived with its heat; now is the time to think about the next year's planning, when the soul will be free from worries.

transliteration.couplet:
Kahe sahu maḷī juvo vichārī, ā gādīnā koṇ adhikārī; <RHYME_40>
Āvyu chhe amārā jāṇyā māī, temā fer raheshe nahi kāī.  <RHYME_40>
transliteration.context: The couplet suggests that a person's thoughts are like a thread, difficult to grasp and hard to assign authority over; just as one's own mother is not absent from their life, so too are these thoughts always present.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context:
Here is a summary of the Gujarati couplet in English:

Rampratap has achieved his desired state of happiness and prosperity; he has obtained the fruit of his thoughts.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context:
When I remember the sweet moments of my past, it's hard to find another seed like it; 
The wise saint says that truth is only found in the present moment, and we should cherish it today.

transliteration.couplet:
Tame karyā chhe sant je ghaṇā, temā paṇ nathī kāī maṇā; <RHYME_43>

transliteration.context: In this couplet, the speaker describes a peaceful soul who is not bothered by worldly desires and attachments. This person has transcended materialism and is focused on their spiritual path.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī pūchhyu paraspar bahune, gamī vāt haiyāmā sahune; <RHYME_44>
Pachhī vītyā thoḍā ghaṇā dan, āvyā Varatāle Jagjīvan.  <RHYME_44>
transliteration.context: As we face each other with difficulties, we must learn to bear the storm together. Just as a small bird's cry echoes loudly in a mountain valley, our Lord Jagjivan is always near us.

transliteration.couplet:
Sarve sambandhī leī sanghāth, āvyā utsav karavā Nāth; <RHYME_45>

transliteration.context: The summary is: "Gather all relationships and celebrate with joy, as the Lord does; Perform the festival of actions and enjoy the best of knowledge."

transliteration.couplet:

Āpī gādī āchāraj kīdhā, tene mandir desh vahechī dīdhā.  <RHYME_46>
transliteration.context: The soul of Raghu's descendant is blessed with the Lord's grace, and his path to salvation is illuminated by devotion. His life's journey takes him to the divine abode, where love and joy forever reside.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: Life's sorrows are reflected in the eyes, but one should not be troubled by others' troubles; I will fulfill my duties and then depart to Gaḍhaḍe village.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: The couplet describes the joy of celebrating Vasant Panchami, a Hindu festival where one seeks divine blessings and good fortune.

transliteration.couplet:
Lāvyā gulāl ne rang ghaṇo, karyo sāmā ramavā taṇo; <RHYME_49>
Ati ānande bharyā chhe Nāth, nākhe chhe rang potāne hāth.  <RHYME_49>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a beautiful and vibrant festival (gulāl) that brings joy to everyone. The husband's happiness is unmatched, with his hands holding onto the colorful threads of celebration.

transliteration.couplet:
Reḍe rang ne nākhe gulāl, teṇe sakhā thayā sahu lāl; <RHYME_50>

transliteration.context: The color of love is not the same as that of others, and its beauty is unique like Lord Krishna's dark complexion. The color of true love is only revealed when it comes into being.

transliteration.couplet:
Sarve vastra thayā range rātā, joī jan tṛupta nathī thātā; <RHYME_51>

transliteration.context:
All external garments are shed, only the pure soul remains; all worldly attachments are left behind like a worn-out boat.

The Lord takes away the ego and attachments, leaving one with nothing but their true self.

transliteration.couplet:
Nāhī āvī jamyā Nāth jan, karyo utsav thaī prasanna; <RHYME_52>

transliteration.context: The devotee's spiritual journey is joyful and festive without the need for an external guide, as the experience of divine bliss brings inner happiness. In this state of ecstasy, one finds supreme joy in the presence of God, Lord Sahajanand.
